I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) will build climate resilience in the hydropower 
investment planning process for better management of climate vulnerability, associated risks, and 
environmental sustainability. The TA will (i) provide analytical works to assess engineering options 
for a climate-smart hydropower design that can adapt to projected climate change risks, (ii) 
establish climate resilience assessment criteria and guidelines, (iii) filter projects and develop a 
hydropower  development  master  plan,  and  (iv)  build  climate  resilience  expertise  into  the 
institutional and policy landscape to improve climate change risk management in Uzbekistan. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
2.  The Uzbek economy grew robustly at an average rate of 8.4% from 2007 to 2016 but is 
projected to slow to an average of 5.0% because of external shocks. The energy sector has 
played a critical role in underpinning Uzbekistan’s sustained growth, contributing 10% of the 
country’s gross domestic product and 25% of exports. However, Uzbekistan is also one of the 
most energy-intensive countries in the world. Its aging and dilapidated Soviet-era energy and 
industrial infrastructure is a major factor behind poor energy efficiency. The lack of adequate 
investments in new power plants across the energy value chain is inhibiting the retirement of old 
power plants and worsening energy efficiency. 
 
3.  Uzbekistan is rich in hydrocarbon resources, with large proven reserves of about 1.8 trillion 
cubic meters of natural gas, 600 million barrels of oil, and 3 billion tons of coal. The primary energy 
consumption in Uzbekistan is dominated by natural gas, which provides 82% of its energy mix.1 
Uzbekistan is the eighth-largest producer of natural gas in the world. In 2016, it produced more 
than 62 billion cubic meters of natural gas, of which 20% was exported. Natural gas also 
dominates the country’s electricity generation mix, contributing 86% of total electricity produced 
in 2017. High reliance on natural gas, compounded by energy inefficiency, has led to (i) missed 
opportunities for higher-value natural gas exports, (ii) limited system reliability and inefficient load 
management, and (iii) high carbon emission and increased vulnerability to long-term unavailability 
of natural gas. 
 
4.  To tackle challenges, Uzbekistan’s energy policy has been shifting toward low greenhouse 
gas (GHG) emission pathways, emphasizing improved energy efficiency and the deployment of 
renewable resources, with an ambitious target to double the share of renewable energy by 2030. 
As part of this initiative, Uzbekistan has adopted a $2.6 billion investment program to modernize 
and construct hydropower plants (HPPs) from 2017 to 2025.2 In 2017, installed hydropower 
generation capacity totaled 1,883.8 megawatts of the 12,000.0-megawatt hydropower potential, 
contributing 13.0% of total electricity generation capacity and 15.8% of the total available supply. 
Successful implementation of the program is expected to increase hydropower capacity by 1.6 
gigawatts by 2030. 
 
5.  With a two-pronged strategy of (i) shifting to a low GHG emission energy system through 
the development of indigenous hydropower resources and (ii) serving the competing water-use 
demand in various economic sectors, the government established the Joint-Stock Company 
                                                
1  Oil (10%), hydropower (5%), and coal (3%) are the other sources in the energy mix. 
2  Government of Uzbekistan. 2017. Resolution of the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan on the Program of 
Measures for Further Development of Hydropower Energy for 2017–2021. No. PP-2947. Tashkent. 2 May.

2 
Uzbekhydroenergo. Uzbekhydroenergo was formed by merging the HPPs of Uzbekenergo, a 
vertically integrated electricity utility, and Uzsuvenergo, a hydropower company under the Ministry 
of  Agriculture  and  Water  Resources.3  The  government’s  massive  hydropower  investment 
program is led by Uzbekhydroenergo. 
 
6.  Large  deployment  of  hydropower  is  seen  as  an  effective  GHG  emission  mitigation 
strategy. However, a significant portion of the country’s water resources comes from mountains 
in neighboring countries, where glaciers supply most of the region’s river runoff. Hydropower, 
particularly run-of-river technology without little or no reserve capacity, is vulnerable to climate 
change-associated decrease in river flows and reduction in water availability. If not carefully 
considered during planning and design, water supply issues could affect the production of 
electricity from HPPs. 
 
7.  Besides  its  adverse  impact  on  electricity generation,  the climate-change  associated 
decrease in accessibility to water resources could worsen the country’s water-stressed situation. 
Hence, in addition to power generation, investments to increase water storage capacity and 
multipurpose dams will be further promoted as a climate change adaptation measure to provide 
water  security  for  drinking,  irrigation,  and  disaster  control.  To  prevent  risks  to  the  overall 
sustainability of watersheds and the environment from worsening, the design and construction of 
hydropower projects should be effectively aligned with the country’s energy and water needs. 
 
8.  The government’s hydropower investment plan is largely based on Soviet-era climate and 
hydrological data without consideration of international climate resilience guidelines. Given the 
challenges  of  climate  variability  and  projected  long-term  reduction  in  water  availability  in 
Uzbekistan, incorporating practical climate-resilience provisions into the hydropower planning 
process will ensure the technical and economical soundness of long-standing investments. In 
addition, given the significant investment needs to develop hydropower projects, catalyzing 
private  sector  investments  in  hydropower  and  exploring  public–private  partnership  (PPP) 
arrangement for financing of hydropower projects are essential. 
 
9.  This transaction TA, which is attached to the Sustainable Hydropower Project, will help 
facilitate the implementation of the government’s hydropower development strategy and address 
climate change challenges that may constrain long-term investments. In particular, the TA will 
facilitate the preparation of a hydropower development master plan to review and rationalize the 
government’s investment plan. The master plan will also explore climate-resilient pathways for 
hydropower development, with greater emphasis on flexibility and climate-smart options that 
perform well under uncertainty. Equivalent efforts will be made to infuse climate resilience into 
energy policy, regulation, and planning to make them climate smart. 
 
10.  The TA project’s impacts, which are aligned with government strategies to lower GHG 
emissions (footnote 2), will be increased reliable energy supply, reduced GHG emissions, and 
improved  sustainability  of  the  energy  sector. The  outcome  will  be  sustainable  hydropower 
generation in Uzbekistan increased. The project is in the country operations business plan, 2019–
2021 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for Uzbekistan,4 and the TA is aligned with ADB’s 
Strategy 2030 priorities to mitigate climate change and enhance environmental sustainability.5 
                                                
3  Government of Uzbekistan. 2017. Resolution of the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan on the Formation of the 
Joint-Stock  Company  ‘Uzbekhydroenergo’  for  the  Effective  Use  of  Hydropower  Resources  and  the  Further 
Development of Hydropower. No. UP-5044. Tashkent. 
4  ADB. 2018. Country Operations Business Plan: Uzbekistan, 2019–2021. Manila. 
5  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila.

3 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
11.  Output 1: Climate resilience promoted in hydropower planning. Output 1 will finance 
the analytical works and integration of climate resilience in the hydropower development master 
plan through the following key activities: (i) reviewing and assessing hydropower in Uzbekistan 
and  its  long-term  development  plan  with  emphasis  on  resilience  to  climate  change  and 
environmental sustainability; (ii) formulating project selection criteria and assessment tools, taking 
technical, financial, environmental, and socioeconomic characteristics and climate resilience into 
account; (iii) conducting due diligence on the planned hydropower projects and developing a 
hydropower sector master plan based on the selection criteria; and (iv) conducting stakeholder 
consultations  and  workshops  to  disseminate  the  outcome  and  knowledge.  During  TA 
implementation, cooperation with neighboring countries will be sought under the Central Asia 
Regional Economic Cooperation Program with possible expansion into a regional cooperation 
agenda. 
 
12.  The master plan will also identify short-term priority investment projects that are urgently 
needed to improve the reliability of power supply, which will eventually be included in the 
government’s investment plan and offered to private sector investments. To this end, early-stage 
due diligence reports, including stakeholder consultations, will be prepared under the master plan, 
including exploration of the PPP modality. 
 
13.  Output 2: Institutional capacity in climate resilience enhanced. Output 2 will build 
capacity to mainstream climate resilience into the institutional and policy landscape throughout 
the implementation of the TA and the preparation of the master plan. The institutional capacity of 
Uzbekhydroenergo, along with other related agencies, in planning and implementing hydropower 
projects will be enhanced to keep the master plan updated and relevant. This output will also help 
broaden  staff  understanding  on  new  technologies,  climate-smart  hydropower  design,  and 
important issues affecting water–energy security. Exploration of PPPs will strengthen the capacity 
of the government and Uzbekhydroenergo in structuring PPP projects, allocating risks, and 
developing templates for various contractual arrangements. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.7 million, of which (i) $1.0 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Climate Change Fund6 and (ii) $0.5 million will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Clean Energy Fund7 under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility and administered by 
ADB. Eligible expenditures include consulting services, training and workshops, and equipment. 
The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. 
 
15.  Uzbekhydroenergo will provide counterpart support in the form of data and information, 
counterpart staff, office accommodation, office supplies, technical staff necessary to accomplish 
the task, and other in-kind contributions. The government was informed that approval of the TA 
does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
                                                
6  Established by ADB. 
7  Financing partners: the governments of Australia, Norway, Spain, Sweden, and the United Kingdom.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  The TA will be implemented from October 2019 to December 2020. ADB will administer 
the TA through the Central and West Asia Department’s Energy Division, with support from the 
Uzbekistan Resident Mission. The division will select, supervise, and recruit consultants. 
 
17.  All TA disbursement will follow ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time). Implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

18.   Consulting services. ADB will engage a consulting firm and individual consultants 
following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time), Procurement 
Regulation for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time), and their associated project 
administration instructions and/or staff instructions.8 The international consulting firm will provide 
27 person-months of international and national consulting services over 37 man-months. Given 
the technical complexity of assignment, ADB will apply the 90:10 quality- and cost-based selection 
method using full technical proposal. Output-based and/or lump-sum contracts will be considered 
for the engagement of international consulting firms, individual consultants, and resource persons; 
and advance contracting will be used to recruit TA consultants under such contracts wherever 
possible. Depending on actual project needs, resource persons may also be required. Any 
additional consultant not envisaged at this time will be recruited individually.
